projectDesc.p: "迷神引" is part of The Global Medieval Sourcebook, a digital compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. This larger project comprises computer-readable transcriptions and/or editions of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century, and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia; accompanied by new English translations; high-resolution digital images of manuscript/early print sources, where available; an apparatus that includes critical introductions, textual notes and annotations; and a flexible user interface with which to navigate these materials.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.rdg: To the Tune “The Lost Soul”
On a thin boat, the light sail is furled up,
temporarily moored by the southern bank of the Chu River.
On the lonesome city walls, the evening horn sounds,
followed by the regretful barbarian lute.
The water is vast and hazy.
The wild geese on the extensive sandbank,
suddenly startled, scatter around.
The mist disperses and cold woods emerges --
a painted screen unfolds:
on the distant edge of the sky, the mountains are small,
(like) her dimly-drawn black eyebrows.
I have thrown away my old love too hastily,
and come here as a drifting official.
I realize the weariness of the journey of a traveler.
The year is late,
the things and scenes of a strange town.
How could I bear the desolation,
in front of my eyes of sorrow?
The capital is faraway,
the way to the Qin building is blocked.
The soul in travel is muddled.
Fragrant grass link up with the spacious sky;
the setting sun shines on all.
There is no message from the fair one;
the solitary patch of cloud is distant.
